title: 'Big stick' unlikely to ever be used
text:
The government's "big stick" energy legislation has breezed through the House of Representatives with the support of Labor but Energy Minister Angus Taylor said it was unlikely the powers would be used.

And despite claims by the government that the laws would help keep down power prices, Treasury officials told Senate estimates on Wednesday that the department has not done any modelling to support this claim.

The legislation, which will enable as a last resort the forced divestment of energy assets as punishment for anti-competitive conduct, will pass the Senate when it next sits in November.

The laws will then come into effect six months later so the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, which would recommend divestment, can first educate the energy companies as to what is expected of them.

Forced divestment, which would have to be ordered by the Federal Court following a recommendation by the ACCC, is the last resort penalty. Before this is contemplated, a company can be told to change its behaviour, fined or have its prices fixed by the Treasurer.

The laws will expire in 2025 and Mr Taylor said it was unlikely they will ever be used.
description: The government's big stick legislation has breezed through the House of Representatives with the support of Labor but Energy Minister Angus Taylor said it was unlikely it would ever be wielded.
